entry.title: Re: RM07DOCS dumped with TSV_TNEW_PAGE_ALLOC_FAILED
entry.content:
You need to convince your BA and educate him/her that MB51 is a powerful report, but it‚Äôs designed to work best when we help it narrow down the data. When we run it with only plant as a filter, it tries to pull millions of records, which is why it crashes or runs out of memory. By adding filters like Posting Date or Movement Type, we‚Äôre not limiting your access ‚Äî we‚Äôre making sure you get the data faster, more reliably, and without system errors.

Still if you are not able to convince, then, you can create a screen variant for mb51 via shd0 with pre-filled values like plant, posting date. Assign it to a user or role. This lets your Business Analyst run MB51 with default filters, even if they don‚Äôt manually enter them.

The other option is to create ZMB51 which should be copy of RM07DOCS Program, where you can add standard variant via se38 or se80 where you can include default filters like Posting Date, Movement Type, etc. This gives full control and avoids dumps ‚Äî especially useful if MB51 is used frequently with minimal filters.

But again, the current practice is strictly not recommended and if needed, you need to take it up to next level

entry.title: Re: Rebate and Royalties in SAP S/4
entry.content:
Hi @sumit_chourasia1 ,

SAP Condition Contract Settlement does not create SD Billing Documents: "Settlement in Condition Contract Management is posted through a Settlement Document directly to FI, so posting through an SD invoice is no longer possible". See 2815535 - FAQ: Condition Contract Management by Settlement Management in SAP S/4HANA - SAP for Me.

It is possible to use multiple data sources for the business volume. For this you have to configure "Additional Business Volume Tables" within the "Profiles for Business Volume Determination". An example for a table that is reading settlement documents is  C_SETLDOCITMSCOMMSNBIZVOL. You find this example in the document CCM_External_Sales_Commissions_Standard_Configuration_2023.pdf. See 2535889 - CCM - Description of delivered configuration - SAP for Me.

Helpful reading: Settlement Management | SAP Community

entry.title: Re: Error while uploading PDF file in "Create supplier in...
entry.content:
Hello @Varun_Arora1 

Thank you for your question.

The error on your attached screenshot is a known issue in SAP S/4HANA Cloud and Fiori apps. This error typically results from either the file not being properly selected, a problem with your Content Version attachment services or a missing parameter in document management configuration.

  • Ensure the PDF file is valid, not empty and correctly selected before clicking upload. You can reselect and again.
  • Consider clearing your browser cache and try a different browser or incognito window.
  • Make sure your SAP DMS is configured and enabled in your environment, as attachments in Fiori rely on corresponding content management settings.

Sometimes, it has happened that backend permissions or temporary system blocks especially after you have carried out migration activities can prevent generating a valid file ID for attachment.

You can open an incident with SAP if the error persists.

The SAP KBA on attachment upload errors provides further details.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Keeping Positions in Sync with Job Info Portlet in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central
entry.content:
Agenda

  1. Why Job Info ‚Üí Position sunchornization matters
  2. Step-by-step configuration with Business Rules
  3. Role of Event Reasons
  4. Best practices to avoid errors
  5. Final thoughts

Why positions and job info must match in Successfactors Employee Central?

Position and Job Info Both should Match. Usually positions have tendency to sync data to job info. That means if you get 1 new update in position then those information can be automatically populated from Position Job Info Via position to Job Info Synchronization.

Why Job Info and Position must match in Successfactors Employee Central?

  • If you have different information on employee profile and on a position, how can you recognize the correct information?
  • So, You need to sync both to avoid mismatch info. If you are not using sync then you're losing automation as the data from the position.
  • In configuration using position management, only use Position-to-Job Info synchronization direction. I strongly recommend you to use Position to Job info Sync in Manage Position management settings to reduce the User error.

How Synchronization works:

  • Go to "Position Management Settings".
  • Navigate to the "Synchronization Tab".
    • The "Synchronization Tab" determines the behavior of the system when synchronizing data from a Position to an employee‚Äôs Job Information. This includes the rules for defining fields used in synchronization of Position to an employee‚Äôs Job Information.
  • Configure the fields that should sync
  • Add Business Rules for triggering updates (e.g., when a position is changed, reflect changes in Job Info).

Step-by-Step: Position to JobInfo Sync Configuration with Business Rule:

Define the Use Case:

  • When a change happens in the Job Information Portlet  (like Department, Division, Location), it should automatically reflect in the Position Object.
  • This is handled via a Business Rule using the Scenario: Synchronize Incumbent‚Äôs Changes to Position Scenario.

Step: 1 - Create the Business Rule:

  1. Go to Configure Business Rules.

  2. Click Create New Rule.

  3. Choose Position Management  - Pre Delivered Template. 

  4. Under Scenario, select: Synchronize Incumbent‚Äôs Changes to Position Scenario.

Step 2 - Register the Rule in Position Management Settings:

  1. Go to Admin Center ‚Üí Position Management Settings.

  2. Navigate to the Synchronization Tab.

  3. Find the field: "Rule for Synchronizing Job Information to Position".

  4. Assign the Business Rule you just created (JobToPos)

  5. Save the configuration.

Step: 3 Event Reason object configuration

  • Event Reasons act as triggers for synchronization.
  • Common examples:
    • Position Transfer ‚Üí when an employee moves to a new role.
      • If you are going to change the position then position transfer will be use as follow up activity.
    • Position Reclassification ‚Üí when department/division updates occur.
      • If you want to change in department and Division then Position Reclassification will be use as follow up activity.
  • These objects ensure accurate, event-driven updates.
  • For the Job info to position Synchronization we need to get help from event reason. On the base of event reason we will get change. Mainly we creates three objects event reason to change happen from Job info to position.

Step: 4 job information portlet and create Business Rule

Prerequisite:

  • First you need to go to Job Information Portlet and check here if we have Event and Event Reason Picklist field is enabled or not.
  • If its enabled and will be visible there then we don‚Äôt need to write the business rule for this case user will select manually.
  • If its not enabled then event and event reason will not come up here so we have write the business rule.

Regards,

Mahnoor Naseem

SAP SuccessFactors Consultant

If you found this blog a useful please consider giving it a Kudos

entry.title: Re: Error creating number group range for range object: E...
entry.content:
Hola @MatiasGarciaKPS 

Thanks for your message. In SAP S/4HANA, Public Cloud, the number range object for eDocument Spain ‚Äì Verifactu (EDOC_ESVF) is delivered as SAP-controlled. This is why the fields appear read-only and why the Copy Subobject option leads to an authorisation error; the system does not allow customers to create or extend ranges for this object.

If you need separate number ranges for multiple companies, the recommended path is to open an SAP Incident under component CA-GTF-CSC-EDO (eDocument Compliance). SAP Support can then confirm whether an enhancement or additional SSCUI option is available for your release.

Check below SAP help references:

SAP Help Portal ‚Äì Spain: Electronic Invoicing with Verifactu

3609812 - FAQ - Electronic Document Processing for Spain VERI*FACTU legal change 2025/2026

SAP Help-Using Evaluated Invoice Settlement

In summary, the observed behaviour is deliberate in Public Cloud, and new ranges for EDOC_ESVF cannot be created directly.

Feel free to reach out when ever you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Building an Attachment Upload and Download Solution Using UploadSetwithTable Control
entry.content:
Hi @tejaswikosanam as I mentioned above, your scenario should be achievable.

When you click upload, you have to create the binding without sending the patch request, which should update the table locally on the UI. Later, when you press the save, you can send your local changes to the backend.

Give it a try in this direction.

An answer to your question in the community:  You can skip the default uploader and use your implementation the same way I am using it in this blog post. All you have to do is put the uploader under the aggregation uploader.

<uploader>
<upload.UploaderTableItem httpRequestMethod="Put"/>
</uploader>

entry.title: SAP Community Team Spotlight: Josh Bentley - September 2025 Edition
entry.content:
You probably have already seen the past interviews of this series (one / two / three / four / five / six / seven / eight ) which were done by my colleague Marco Santos. Today I am very excited to introduce you to another amazing person behind the SAP Community platform. Here we are with another SAP Community Spotlight, @josh_bentley ! 

 

Fatemeh Zarei (FZ): Hi Josh! Thank you so much for joining us today. To kick things off - would you like to tell us a little bit about your iconic blue beard? How did that all start?

Josh Bentley: So, every superhero has their own origin story - mine's just a little less dramatic. I‚Äôve been talking about technology for nearly 25 years, and in 2018, I joined the Developer Advocates team after leaving the Cloud Center of Excellence. At a conference - SAP TechEd - the women on our team had all these vibrant hair colors and teased us guys for being boring. I thought, ‚ÄúWhy is it only the women showing personality?‚Äù But I don‚Äôt have hair - I‚Äôm bald! So, one of them said, ‚ÄúWell, you can dye your beard.‚Äù I didn‚Äôt take it seriously at first, but before SAP TechEd in 2019, I thought, "Why not?" I texted her for tips, used paper towels to mix colors until I got close to SAP blue, and I‚Äôve kept it ever since. This October marks six years! What keeps me doing it is not just for my ego boost but for the smiles I get from others and the joy they truly show me when they see me.

FZ: That‚Äôs fantastic! Now, shifting gears a bit - how did you first get involved with the SAP Community?

Josh: That goes back to my pre-sales days, around 2011 or 2012, when we had the ‚ÄúBlog It Forward‚Äù campaign that Moshe Naveh started. I was a solution engineer at the time and joined in by answering the campaign questions, then tagging others. That was my first real blog post and entry into the community. I wasn‚Äôt one of the founders or key players at the start - it was more of a resource to find answers or share thoughts. But that‚Äôs where it began for me.

FZ: What's your current role on the SAP Community team, and what does a typical day look like?

Josh: These days, I focus on promoting community advocacy. I help highlight what‚Äôs working and where we can improve. My work is all about connecting with people - online and in person - and making sure their voices are heard. There‚Äôs no ‚Äútypical‚Äù day, but it involves a mix of content creation, listening to feedback, and strategizing how to make the community better.

FZ: You‚Äôve done so much! What‚Äôs one part of the SAP community experience that you‚Äôre particularly proud of?

Josh: It‚Äôs hard to pick one, but I‚Äôll mention three chapters in my SAP life. First, I was part of the team that transitioned SAP from BlackBerry to Apple devices, which was a major enterprise shift. We tackled security, analytics access, BYOD - it was a huge cross-functional effort. Then in pre-sales, I traveled extensively and gave technical demos to some of the biggest companies in the world. I got comfortable and confident in front of customers because I prepared so thoroughly - ‚Äúsharpening the axe,‚Äù as they say. And in the Developer Advocate role, one big highlight was being trusted to go on stage for SAP TechEd, even during the COVID era when we broadcasted from Frankfurt. Being able to be myself and present on a global stage was unforgettable.

FZ: Amazing. Do you have a favorite or most memorable moment in the community?

Josh: One standout was my first SAP TechEd in Barcelona. Being in a role where I get to visit an amazing city like that is something else, but the real magic was seeing the show floor and the scale of how many SAP mentors and other legacy members made the trip. Some of my first SAP selfies with people I would work with for years were taken at that event.

FZ: How do you stay in tune with the community‚Äôs needs and feedback?

Josh: Three main ways. First, in-person events. That‚Äôs where people are really open. Online, they might not comment or engage as much, but in person they‚Äôll say, ‚ÄúHey, I saw your video!‚Äù Second, I post on YouTube and LinkedIn to keep communication flowing. Third, I look at outside platforms like Reddit or Stack Overflow to see what SAP techies are saying in the wild.

FZ: If you could wave a magic wand and change one thing in the community, what would it be?

Josh: I‚Äôd love to see more people offering constructive feedback - with solutions in mind. Not just ‚Äúthis is broken,‚Äù but ‚Äúhere‚Äôs how it could be better.‚Äù I know we can‚Äôt always implement every suggestion - due to technology limitations or staffing - but the community is stronger when members help shape it. The community is bigger than just a website. It‚Äôs every conversation, every event. And we need our members to be co-owners in it.

FZ: And one final question - do you have any advice for those new to SAP or the SAP Community, like me?

Josh: Absolutely. Be your own advocate. No one else is going to push you harder than you will. Learn how your managers listen. In meetings - listen first. Figure out how you can add value. People ask how they can have a role like mine. I say, there are two ways: either start a company and create your own path - or gain experience over time. I didn‚Äôt go to school for SAP. I started wiring buildings, setting up IT systems, and just kept learning. Over time, I built a brand and a reputation for being honest, responsive, and knowledgeable. Have a point of view - or put in the work. There‚Äôs no shortcut. Just engage with kindness and curiosity, and the rest will come.

FZ:  What a wonderful way to wrap things up! Thank you so much, Josh, for joining me today and sharing your SAP journey with us. It‚Äôs been a real pleasure having you here.

Josh: Thanks, Fatemeh. I really enjoyed our conversation.

entry.title: Re: Send Stock SAP MM to another application
entry.content:
Yes via message type MBGMCR, SAP can send IDocs automatically when a material document is posted, depending on your setup. You‚Äôll need to configure output type in NACE for application MB. Assign a partner profile in WE20 and ensure the function module like IDOC_OUTPUT_WMMBXY is active. The advantage of having this set up is easy to monitor via WE02/WE05 and can be extended with user exits if needed. but on the other side, this requires IDoc infrastructure and mapping on the third-party side.

The other option is BAdI MB_DOCUMENT_BADI or EXIT_SAPMM07M_001 to intercept MIGO posting. From there, trigger a custom API call, a queue Or even write to a Z-table for later extraction. The advantage of going with this approach are full control over payload and timing and can be tailored to specific movement types. On the other side, it involves risk of performance impact if not handled asynchronously.

If your third-party system supports IDoc or can consume it via middleware like PI/CPI, go with Option 1 (IDoc MBGMCR or WMMBXY). It is clean, standard, and scalable. If you need real-time push with custom payload, go with Option 2 (BAdI) and trigger a REST API or queue.

entry.title: Re: ÂÆ¢Êà∑ÂØπS/4HANA Public CloudÁöÑË¥¶Â•óÈúÄÊ±Ç
entry.content:
Hello @JuliaLu ,

According to your requirement, it seems the parallel accounting requirement is as follow: one ledger for group accounting principle (Austria GAAP), one ledger for local ledger (Local GAAP) and one ledger group valuation(4G).

For parallel accounting, the recommendation is:
Leading ledger 0L  -> corporate accounting principle (IFRS/USGAAP or country/region-specific accounting principle)
Non-leading ledger 2L or 3L -> country/region-specific accounting principle(s).

The delivered system default is that the leading ledger is assigned to the local accounting principle, as a local ledger is always needed and you could have one ledger only. As soon as you have more than one ledger, SAP recommendation is to change this default. This means that you need to change the default assignments in configuration as shown above.

For your case:

0L -> Austria GAAP , maintain at corp AccPr level

2L-> Local GAAP, maintain at company code level

Please also note that you can only change the assignment of accounting principles to ledgers and company codes before the first posting in the system.

Reference: 

3530183 - Assigning Accounting Principles to Ledgers and Company Codes in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Details on Configuration in General Ledger Accounting and Asset Accounting - SAP for Me

Question 16~22 in the In-Depth are suitable for your case:

In-Depth with SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Ledger Scoping Q&A - SAP Community

Kind Regards,

entry.title: Re: Connect SAP Workflow Sevice in the NEO environment to My Inbox on-premise
entry.content:
Hello,

although it has been a while since the last comment and the blog entry is quite old, I would like to make this response because I believe there are still many people out there looking for a solution to integrate cloud workflows into the on-premise Fiori inbox.

According to latest update of the SAP note 3071334 that refers to this blog entry, SAP still can not offer a standard integration approach.

However, since one of last updates to the SAP Build Process Automation Workflow API, we have been finally able to manage to successfully integrate our SAP Process Automation based approval tasks into the Fiori on-premise inbox on a project basis! To do this, we implemented a custom task provider for the on-premise Fiori Inbox, that queries the user's SBPA tasks and displays them in the Fiori Inbox. This allows us to use the on-premise Fiori Inbox as a true central task inbox again.

If you are also still looking for an integration option, please take a look at the current spec for the SAP Process Automation Workflow API in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Best regards
Markus

entry.title: Re: How to define the scrap value?
entry.content:
When maintaining the depreciation area-specific asset master data, you can specify an absolute scrap value, and/or a percentage rate, in the detail screen of each depreciation area. If you enter both, the system uses the percentage by default.

If a cutoff value key is assigned to the depreciation key, the system ignores the cutoff value percentage of the key and treats the amount entered in the asset master record as the scrap value.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3e5fcf2c768746049b5627bd5a42f720/8f2cd25320cd4608e10000000a174cb4.html?version=LATEST&locale=en-US

entry.title: Goodbye UI5 Tooling - Hello UI5 CLI!
entry.content:
Over the last decade, UI5 Tooling became the best-in-class tool to develop UI5 projects. It offers a range of features to make your life as a developer easy when serving and building projects using the powerful UI5 framework. In this blogpost, I'll explain the reasons behind the renaming of "UI5 Tooling" to "UI5 CLI".

 

History 

In 2018, when we released the initial version of UI5 Tooling, we used the rather technical-sounding term "UI5 Build and Development Tooling". Already in 2018, we had several discussions about which name would fit best for the project and at that point in time we came up with the shortened term "UI5 Tooling".  

Right from the beginning, we've designed UI5 Tooling modular and extensible, which led to a large and highly engaged community offering various extensions. It's amazing to see how many builder tasks and server middlewares are developed and maintained by the UI5 community. The UI5 community plays a crucial role in the whole UI5 ecosystem. Currently, UI5 Tooling comprises six packages, namely @ui5/cli, @ui5/server, @ui5/builder, @ui5/project, @ui5/fs and @ui5/logger. Despite this modularization, most developers only use@ui5/cli, which includes all the other packages. As you might notice, there is no package name including the term "tooling". This led to the situation that many developers talk about "UI5 CLI" when in fact talking about UI5 Tooling. So we're having two terms for the same project, which is not ideal.  

In 2019, the first version of SAP Fiori tools was released. SAP Fiori tools is a project developed by SAP and offering a wide range of tools to develop SAP Fiori applications more efficiently. It's not only focusing on UI5 but also on further aspects, such as e.g. SAP Fiori elements. SAP Fiori tools contains UI5 Tooling and puts additional functionality on top. If you develop an SAP Fiori application, SAP Fiori tools is the right choice for you. In the meantime, some modules of SAP Fiori tools have also been open-sourced. In 2019, SAP Fiori Tools decided to choose "@sap/ux-ui5-tooling" as its package name, which highlights perfectly the close relationship to the underlying UI5 Tooling project. However, these similar names led to a lot of confusion in the SAP customer and open-source community base. There is no "@ui5/tooling" package on npmjs.org but a package called "@sap/ux-ui5-tooling", which is not UI5 Tooling but actually SAP Fiori tools. That's confusing.  

 

Motivation 

Over the last years, it turned out that keeping the term UI5 Tooling led to much confusion on the consumer side, which then resulted in an increasing support effort on our side. So, we made up our minds over several iterations about what would be the best new name for our tool. Finally, we settled on the term UI5 CLI as our successor term for UI5 Tooling.

 

Good to know 

First, and very importantly, this rename does not affect / disrupt your coding. The packages published on npmjs.org won't change their names.  

Over the next weeks, we'll migrate https://github.com/SAP/ui5-tooling to its new home on the newly created UI5 GitHub organization, and we'll ensure that any old links will be redirected to the new location. As soon as the new repository is available, we recommend updating your bookmarks. We'll use this new repository as a monorepo containing all UI5 CLI-related projects. The other UI5 CLI-related repositories will stay on the SAP GitHub organization and hold the source code for Version 4 and prior releases. The new monorepo will contain the source code for the next major version, for which we'll start the development phase soon, as well as the documentation for all UI5 CLI releases. 

There are already plenty of new features planned for UI5 CLI and we're looking forward to giving you an update on them soon. 

Note: We'll add the URLs of the new repository landscape here as soon as they're available.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4 Public Cloud - Historical Balances Migration...
entry.content:
Hello @Luis_Amaral_Rib43 

Thank you for your question. I‚Äôve reviewed your scenario, and what you are seeing is standard system behaviour in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition.

Why is the opening balance zero?

The migration object FI ‚Äì Historical Balances posts balances as periodic entries within the chosen fiscal year. These are visible in reports such as Display G/L Account Balances.

However, these postings do not create an opening balance for the next financial year.

The ‚ÄúOpening Balance‚Äù line in the reports is filled only by the Balance Carryforward process (in on-premise this is FAGLGVTR; in Public Cloud this is either scheduled automatically at year-end or triggered via the Carry forward G/L Balances app).

If you load balances into period 12/2024, the system treats them as actual postings for 2024. When the year-end carryforward runs, these balances are reclassified into period 0/2025. That is why loading directly into 2025 does not populate the opening balance line.

What this means for your project

There is no supported way to migrate balances directly as an ‚Äúopening balance‚Äù for 2025.

The recommended approach is:

Use the migration object to load balance up to fiscal year 2024.

Run the Balance Carryforward (automatically or via Carryforward G/L Balances).

The system will then generate the opening balances for 2025, which will appear correctly in reporting.

SAP Help Portal ‚Äì Migrate Historical G/L Account Balances

SAP Help Portal ‚Äì Carryforward G/L Balances

In summary

You are not doing anything wrong. The zero-opening balance for 2025 is expected if you try to migrate it directly. The correct process is to migrate up to 2024 and then let the system‚Äôs carry-forward logic generate the opening balance for 2025.

Let me know if you need further information

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: How to restrict external planner to see only assigned...
entry.content:
Discuss with your Security team and check for the below option

Have a separate role for your External Planner. Restrict access only to view activities assigned to them. Key permission for Activity.Read, set to ‚ÄúAssigned to me‚Äù or ‚ÄúAssigned to my resource‚Äù. Further, in the Activity List view, apply a default filter like Assigned Technician = [Current User]. You can set this as a default filter for the role so external planners always see only their own activities.

We have work center "Mechanical", in scheduling tab we have field Std Que time value filled with 2HR.

We have work center "Electrical", in scheduling tab we have field Std Que time value filled with 3HR.

and now we have order with several operations with the above work centers.

In general the scheduling will happen as below.

Mechanical - Operations 1 - 5Hrs - start time 08:00:00 end time 13:00:00

Mechanical - Operations 2 - 2Hrs - start time 13:00:00 end time 15:00:00

Electrical - Operations 3 - 1Hrs - start time 15:00:00 end time 16:00:00

 

Now requirement is like below

Mechanical - Operations 1 - 5Hrs - start time 08:00:00 end time 13:00:00  + 2HR Que time

Mechanical - Operations 2 - 2Hrs - start time 15:00:00 end time 17:00:00  + 2HR Que time

Electrical - Operations 3 - 1Hrs - start time 19:00:00 end time 20:00:00

que time should be considered for each operation, even if the work center for next operation is changed then the que time of that work center should be considered.

The request is for they wanted a que time for transfer of that equipment from one work center to another work center. So operation cannot be started immediately after the completion of first operation.

Please provide your thoughts to achieve this requirement.

entry.title: Experience data in SAP Signavio Process Intelligence: new strategic partnership with Medallia
entry.content:
First introduced as part of our April 2025 product release, we shared a new technology partnership with Medallia, a market leader in experience management. This collaboration is designed to help organizations take the next step in process mining by seamlessly combining operational data with human experience data, delivering a more holistic view of business processes and the people impacted by them. 

In this blog, we‚Äôll take a closer look at the partnership and explore how this collaboration brings added value to you by delivering more human-centric insights across your processes. 

From data to insight: the power of experience in process analysis 

Traditionally, process mining has focused on analyzing system-generated data such as event logs. But in today‚Äôs experience-driven competitive environment, that‚Äôs no longer enough. Businesses must also understand how customers, suppliers, and employees experience the process as they move through it. 

This is where Medallia and SAP Signavio come together. Medallia enables organizations to collect rich omnichannel experience data, which include but not limited to survey responses, feedback forms, conversation transcripts and digital behavioural signals. SAP Signavio Process Intelligence then ingests this experience data and correlates it with operational event logs, creating a powerful bridge between people and process. 

A seamless integration via SAP Integration Suite 

Customers using Medallia can now bring their experience data directly into SAP Signavio Process Intelligence. This can be done using various connectivity options available in SAP Signavio, with the recommended approach being through SAP Integration Suite which is a comprehensive, cloud-native integration platform that enables businesses to connect applications, data, and processes securely across on-premise, cloud, and hybrid landscapes with prebuilt connectors, APIs, and intelligent automation. 

An integration package is already available on SAP Business Accelerator Hub as a community release, making it easy to get started. This package includes pre-built integration flows, artifacts, and detailed documentation that can be directly used, configured, and customized to meet specific customer requirements. 

Unlocking new AI-powered insights 

Once the data is inside SAP Signavio Process Intelligence, customers can use the  AI-assisted context analyzer (currently in beta) to extract deeper meaning from qualitative experience data. Two key features are now available: 

Text-to-Event matching: Matches feedback data with specific process events, assuming a common identifier (e.g., Case ID). This enables direct mapping of human feedback to process steps and is visualized using the process discovery widget. 

Sentiment analysis: Automatically labels each experience data entry (e.g., survey comment) as positive, negative, or neutral, and integrates this AI-generated column into the event log. These sentiment insights can then be visualized and analyzed using the table widget, alongside other process performance metrics. 

Of course, all other widgets and visualization tools in SAP Signavio Process Intelligence remain fully available, allowing teams to layer sentiment and feedback insights across broader process analyses. 

Why this matters 

Combining Medallia‚Äôs experience data with SAP Signavio‚Äôs powerful process mining capabilities means businesses no longer have to choose between operational excellence and customer satisfaction. With this integration, you can: 

  • Make decisions based not just on efficiency, but on how people experience your processes 
  • Detect pain points earlier, across the customer journey, supplier onboarding, or employee workflows 
  • Drive transformation that‚Äôs truly human-centered 

Ready to get started? 

Medallia is listed on SAP store where you can learn more about its capabilities. 
If you're already using both Medallia and SAP Signavio, reach out to explore how you can unlock the full potential of this integration.  
Together, SAP Signavio and Medallia are redefining what it means to truly understand your processes, from the inside and outside.

entry.title: Hide/Disable the Select option range in extension
entry.content:
TYPE-POOLS : scarr.
TABLES: scarr.

DATA: wa_res TYPE sscr_restrict,
wa_option_list TYPE sscr_opt_list,
wa_ass TYPE sscr_ass.

INITIALIZATION.
PERFORM initialization.

FORM initialization .
DATA: lv_program TYPE sy-repid,
wa_restriction TYPE sscr_restrict.

lv_program = sy-repid.
wa_option_list-name = 'S_TOEML'.
wa_option_list-options-eq = 'X'.
APPEND wa_option_list TO wa_res-opt_list_tab.

wa_option_list-name = 'S_CCEML'.
wa_option_list-options-eq = 'X'.
APPEND wa_option_list TO wa_res-opt_list_tab.

wa_ass-kind = 'S'.
wa_ass-name = 'S_TOEML'.
wa_ass-sg_main = 'I'.
wa_ass-op_main = 'S_TOEML'.
APPEND wa_ass TO wa_res-ass_tab.

wa_ass-kind = 'S'.
wa_ass-name = 'S_CCEML'.
wa_ass-sg_main = 'I'.
wa_ass-op_main = 'S_CCEML'.
APPEND wa_ass TO wa_res-ass_tab.
*wa_restriction

CALL FUNCTION 'SELECT_OPTIONS_RESTRICT'
EXPORTING
program = sy-repid
restriction = wa_res
* DB = ' '
EXCEPTIONS
too_late = 1
repeated = 2
selopt_without_options = 3
selopt_without_signs = 4
invalid_sign = 5
empty_option_list = 6
invalid_kind = 7
repeated_kind_a = 8
OTHERS = 9.
IF sy-subrc <> 0.
MESSAGE ID sy-msgid TYPE sy-msgty NUMBER sy-msgno
WITH sy-msgv1 sy-msgv2 sy-msgv3 sy-msgv4 DISPLAY LIKE 'E'.
ENDIF.
ENDFORM.

entry.title: Re: how to handle discount on fixed price customer project?
entry.content:
Hello @Meenu_Wavie 

Thank you for your question. This behaviour is common in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Why DCM2 works only for T&E
The discount condition DCM2 (Customer Project Discount) is part of the standard pricing process for T&E (PSP0) projects, which is why it applies there. However, for Fixed Price (PNG1) projects, this condition is not included in the provided pricing process, so no discount is applied.

How to enable discounts for Fixed Price
In Public Cloud, pricing procedures cannot be edited directly. Instead, you must use Central Business Configuration (CBC) ‚Äî specifically, the Price Calculation activities ‚Äì to add a discount condition (such as DCM2 or a custom condition) to the pricing setup for Fixed Price projects.

Output forms
The default output format is Project Billing ‚Äì Customer Invoice (SAP Billing Document Output), which shows gross price, discount, and net price. If you require the specific format ‚Äúprice ‚Üí discount ‚Üí final amount" as you described, you can copy and modify the form in the Form Template Maintenance app.

SAP Help Portal ‚Äì Form Template Maintenance

SAP Learning/Adding the Maintain Form Templates App to the SAP Fiori Launchpad

SAP Help-Plan Customer Projects

Discounts are automatically applied for T&E. For Fixed Price, however, you must set up a discount condition in CBC, and the invoice form will display the discount lines once they are included in the pricing.

Let me know if you need further information

With regards

Chuma

Hi Ramesh, we have been facing with same issue almost 2 years ago, had a call with SAP and they tried to convict me thats logical and working as expected...

 

Create the variable similar to mine:

=If GetPreferredViewingLocale() = "pl_PL" 
Then Replace([cost];" ";"")
ElseIf GetPreferredViewingLocale() = "en_US" 
Then Replace(Replace(Replace([cost];" ";"");",";"");".";",")

But in your case you have to force SAP BO to read correct Date Format. Diffrent for en_US and diffrent for en_UK.

Hope that will help!

entry.title: Seamless Integration of Google Cloud BigQuery with SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC): Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
On a recent project, I integrated Google Cloud BigQuery with SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC). After exploring both platforms, I‚Äôve put together a simple, step-by-step guide‚Äîplus a few key features‚Äîto help you connect them quickly. BigQuery handles huge datasets with speed, while SAC turns that data into clear reports, dashboards, and plans. Together, they take you from raw numbers to smarter decisions.

In this blog, I‚Äôll show you exactly how to set up the integration‚Äîfrom creating a table in BigQuery to keeping your SAC model updated and refreshed.

Key Benefits of BigQuery‚ÄìSAC Integration

  • Seamless Cloud-to-Cloud Integration ‚Äì No complex middleware; connect directly between GCP and SAC.
  • Analytics Made Simple: SAC lets you turn data into dashboards, forecasts, and actionable insights.
  • Faster Decision-Making ‚Äì SAC visualizations update as soon as data refreshes, giving near real-time insights.
  • Collaboration Made Easy ‚Äì SAC allows teams across finance, operations, and strategy to work with the same live data.
  • Automation ‚Äì Schedule regular refreshes so your dashboards and reports stay up to date automatically.

Prerequisites

Before we dive in, you‚Äôll need:

  1. A Google Cloud project with BigQuery enabled.
  2. Access to an SAP Analytics Cloud tenant with permissions to create models and connections.
  3. A BigQuery dataset and an SAC model that share the same schema. (The column data types in BigQuery must match the dimensions and measures in your SAC model.)

Step 1: Create a Table in Google BigQuery

  1. Open GCP Console and navigate to BigQuery Studio.
  2. Create a Dataset within your GCP project.
  3. Within the dataset, create a Table and define its schema. Ensure the schema aligns with the structure of your SAC model (synchronized dimensions and measures). Since I created a table with multiple data types, you can see its schema in the image below.

  4. Populate the table with data if it‚Äôs empty. You can do this via:

    • Python Notebook in GCP .
    • Manual uploads (CSV/JSON).

Example workflow to load data into a BigQuery table (if it has no existing data): Navigate to 'Notebooks' within your GCP project, open a new notebook, load the data using Python, and then verify that the table is populated with the required test or business data. For this example, I loaded some test data into the table using Python code in a notebook.       

Step 2: Prepare the Model in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

  1. Log in to SAP Analytics Cloud.
  2. Navigate to Modeler and create a Blank Model.
  3. Ensure the model structure (dimensions and measures) matches the BigQuery table schema.The image below shows the measures and dimensions, with data types matching those in the BigQuery table.

Step 3: Create a Connection Between SAC and BigQuery

  1. In SAC, go to Main Menu > Connections.
  2. Click on Add Connection (+).
  3. Choose Google BigQuery.
  4. Sign in using the same Google account linked to your GCP project.
  5. Once authenticated, select the relevant Project from the dropdown.
  6. Save the connection. You‚Äôve now linked SAC with your BigQuery environment.

Step 4: Import Data from BigQuery into SAC

  1. Navigate to your SAC model and open Data Management.
  2. Select Import Job.
  3. Choose Google BigQuery as the data source.
  4. Select the connection you created earlier.

      5. Choose between:

  • Freehand SQL Query (for custom queries).
  • Build a Query (drag-and-drop interface) (For most use cases, Build a Query works best: - Select your dataset and table. - Add all required dimensions and measures. - Finalize your query). Here, I chose the Build a Query option, as shown in the image below.

6.  Configure the import job by:

  • Preparing the data.
  • Mapping dimensions to facts
  • Reviewing and confirming the import steps.

7. Run the import. Once completed, SAC will display a success notification along with row-level details in the job timeline.

Step 5: Validate the Imported Data

  1. Navigate back to your Model Structure Workspace in SAC.
  2. Verify that the data has been successfully imported.
  3. Ensure measures and dimensions are mapped correctly.
  4. Test the model with basic visualizations or planning functions to confirm accuracy.
  5. As shown in the image below, the entire BigQuery table is now visible in the Data Foundation area.

Step 6: Refresh and Schedule Your Import Job

One-time imports are fine for demos, but real business data changes constantly. Luckily, SAC lets you refresh and schedule updates:

  • Update: Brings in the latest changes while keeping existing data.
  • Append: Adds new rows without touching what‚Äôs already there.
  • Clean and Replace: Wipes the old dataset and replaces it with fresh data.

You can also schedule refreshes (daily, weekly, or custom) so your dashboards are always up to date ‚Äî no manual work required.

Key Takeaways

  • Integration is straightforward once the schemas in BigQuery and SAC are aligned.
  • BigQuery serves as a powerful backend, while SAC empowers users with visualization and planning tools.
  • Refresh options and scheduling help keep your models in sync automatically

Conclusion

Integrating Google BigQuery with SAP Analytics Cloud isn‚Äôt complicated, but it‚Äôs incredibly powerful. With just a few steps, you can combine BigQuery‚Äôs scalable data engine with SAC‚Äôs interactive analytics and planning features. Whether you‚Äôre experimenting with test data or working at an enterprise level, the process is the same: build your table, set up your model, connect, import, validate, and schedule updates.

By following the steps in this guide, you can set up the integration with ease and keep your models refreshed automatically.
